speaker: Teacher
text: So "un peu" was "a little," "a little." So "a" is "un," spelled "U-N." And again, that N is getting swallowed up. It's at the end of the syllable. It's getting swallowed up and affecting the vowel before it. We know that a U is like in "tu," no? But here it sounds "un" [nasal 'un' sound] peu because the N is getting swallowed up into it and changing that vowel. So "un" [nasal 'un' sound] is "a," "a little," "un peu." [nasal 'un' sound] How would you say "a cake"? "A gateau."

speaker: Teacher
text: Un [nasal 'un' sound] café." So the N is not really pronounced, no? We don't go so much into it. It's just affecting the vowel before it. "Un café." [nasal 'un' sound] How is, again, "you want"? "You want"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Tu veux." So the U of "tu" is quite different to the U of "un," [nasal 'un' sound] no? "Tu veux." And how would you say, "do you want"? You know, more proper or formal way of making questions. "Do you want"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Veux-tu." "Do you want a cake"? [laughs] "Do you want a cake"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Veux-tu un [nasal 'un' sound] gateau"? "Veux-tu un [nasal 'un' sound] gateau"? "Do you want a coffee"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Veux-tu un [nasal 'un' sound] café"? "Un," spelled "U-N," is for masculine nouns, those that take "le" for "the" and "it." For feminine, for feminine nouns like "la baguette," "la bicyclette," "la situation," "la porte," we have "une."

speaker: Teacher
text: And this is spelled "U-N-E." So this E on the end of "une" is like the feminine E that we've seen on the end of other feminine nouns, no? Like "la porte," like "chose," which is also feminine, the word for thing, "la chose," spelled "C-H-O-S-E." "La baguette." So the E on the end of "une" is like this feminine E, so that can remind us that "une" is for feminine words. And this E is also showing us now that we pronounce that N. The N is not on the end of the syllable anymore. We have two syllables now, "u-ne." Even though we don't generally pronounce that last E on the end, that's still like part of a separate syllable. So the 'u' sound is just like in "tu." And then we just get "une" [pronounced N] in most dialects of French. But of course, we could also hear "une" [pronounced N] with the e on the end. So "U-N-E," "une," [pronounced N] for "A" for feminine words.

speaker: Teacher
text: How would you say, "do you want a baguette"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Veux-tu une [pronounced N] baguette?" Or like I mentioned, in some dialects of French we might hear "une," [pronounced N] but if we had that accent to pronounce the E on the end of "une," then we would also do that on "baguette." "Veux-tu une [pronounced N] baguette"? But that's not so common in French. "Can you prepare an invitation"? Of course, "an" and "A" is the same in English, no? And it's just what we have before vowels in English, so "an" or "A" is both "une" here. So "can you prepare an invitation"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Peux-tu préparer une [pronounced N] invitation?" What was again "I must" or "I owe," related to "debt" in English?

speaker: Teacher
text: Je dois." Good. Spelled "D-O-I-S," no? We have the final S there silent. And we also have the "O-I" there, that combination of "O-I" giving us the 'wa' sound, "dois." [French 'wa' sound] What was "to see"? Like view in English.

speaker: Teacher
text: Voir." [French 'wa' sound] Good. We have "V-O-I." So again, the "O-I" there giving us the 'oi' sound, R, with an R on the end, "voir." [French 'wa' sound] And we hear that R on the end. How would you say, "you must see the confirmation"? [nasal 'a' sound] "You must see the confirmation." [nasal 'a' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois voir la confirmation." [nasal 'a' sound] "I just want to see the invitation." [nasal 'in' sound] "I want just to see the invitation." [nasal 'in' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Good, but I think you were holding on to "voir" at the beginning, and just said "je voir." [laughs].

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux juste voir l'invitation." [nasal 'in' sound] So we see how "O-I" gives us an 'oi' sound, "dois," [French 'wa' sound] "voir," [French 'wa' sound] "voiture." [French 'wa' sound] We know the word for car. And as you would have noticed, French has a lot of vowel sounds, no? So it's a good idea to consciously notice, which isn't memorizing, it's just getting yourself into the habit of noticing, to consciously notice different combinations of vowels and the sounds they give us. We've seen "EU," no? As in, "peu," "un peu," [nasal 'un' sound] "je peux," as in, "veux." And we've seen "O-I," for example, as in "dois," [French 'wa' sound] "voir," [French 'wa' sound] "voiture." [French 'wa' sound] We could also see this "O-I" combination in some French words we have in English too, such as "reservoir." Uh, "memoire," we have in English as well. "Memoire" or "noir," for example, which sometimes makes its way into English. "Noir," "noir," in French, which means "black." Uh, we use this in, for example, "film noir," no? "Black film."

speaker: Teacher
text: Or maybe you've seen "Le Chat Noir," which is spelled like "Le Chat Noir," that kind of... That really famous poster of a black cat. Have you seen it? The drawing of a black cat? This is-

speaker: Teacher
text: So, you know, uh, we have that in English as well, "noir." Sometimes, like I said, like in "Film Noir." And actually when we say "Film Noir," we are employing a French habit. We don't say "black film," as you would say in English. We say "film black." No, "Film Noir," and that's a French habit. How was "the cake"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Le gateau," good. So in French, if we want to say "the black cake," we will say "the cake black," just like "Film Noir" where we say "Film Black" or "Le Chat Noir" where we say "the cat black." So "the black cake"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. "Le Gateau Noir." How was "coffee" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. So coffee is masculine now, "le café," even though it ends with an E, which we've said is generally a mark of a feminine word, although the E on "café" is accented and, and always pronounced. "Le café." So if you want to say "the black coffee"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Le café noir." "A black coffee"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. So if we forget about the pronunciation of A, we can just look back to "un peu," [nasal 'un' sound] "a little," "a little," "un peu." [nasal 'un' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: How do we say, "Do you want" with, with the inversion? How is that, "Do you want"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Veux-tu." "Do you want a black coffee"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Veux-tu un [nasal 'un' sound] café noir"? "You must prepare a black coffee." [nasal 'un' sound] "You must prepare a black coffee." [nasal 'un' sound] And this could also mean one black coffee. You must prepare one black coffee.

speaker: Student
text: Tu dois préparer un café noir.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois préparer un [nasal 'un' sound] café noir." "You must prepare it." And with this it, we mean the black coffee. You must prepare it.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois le préparer." So when we have "le" or "la" as it, he, she, now it comes closer to the verb referring to it. And of course, the same applies for "me," no? Which was... What was "me" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Me." [schwa sound] Good. "You must see me later." [schwa sound] "You must see me later." [schwa sound]

speaker: Student
text: Tu dois me voir plus tard.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois me [schwa sound] voir plus tard." So the information there in French comes in a slightly different order now. You must me to see later. "You must prepare me." [schwa sound] How would you say that? "You must prepare me." [schwa sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois me [schwa sound] preparer." "You must see the introduction." [nasal 'in' sound] "You must see the introduction." [nasal 'in' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: You're a bit insecure about the pronunciation of "introduction," no?

speaker: Student
text: Yes, it is a bit difficult.

speaker: Teacher
text: So just take some time to go through each syllable. Now think about how it will sound. So the first bit?

speaker: Teacher
text: So at the end there, we have "duc-tion." [French 'sion' sound] "L'introduc-tion." [nasal 'in' sound, French 'sion' sound] We have C like 'cuh' and then the T like 'suh.' [laughs] Very good. So give it to me altogether and you don't have to hold onto that in your memory, no? What you need to hold onto is the process which is taking your time to go through it slowly and whatever time you need to be sure about what you're doing. So "you must see the introduction." [nasal 'in' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Tu dois voir l'introduc-tion." [nasal 'in' sound, French 'sion' sound] "To introduce." "To introduce," in the sense of introducing people. For this you will say "to present" in French rather than trying to find "to introduce." So how would "to present" be in French? "To present"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Presentation." [nasal 'an' sound, French 'sion' sound] So we have "P-R-E," the E with an accent, so we get "pre" with this 'eh' sound. And then we have "S-E-N." This S sounds like a Z like in English, "presentation." [nasal 'an' sound, French 'sion' sound] But we have "E-N." We have an N on the end of a syllable so that's going to be sucked into the E which changes the sound. "Present," [nasal 'an' sound] "presentation." [nasal 'an' sound, French 'sion' sound] Like in the number "30" which was "trente" [nasal 'a' sound] and there we had "T-R-E-N-T-E." So how would "to present" be? "To present"?

speaker: Teacher
text: And the S is like a Z, the S between vowels. "Présenter." [nasal 'an' sound] "Can you introduce me"? [schwa sound] "Can you present me"? [schwa sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Peux-tu me [schwa sound] présenter? [nasal 'an' sound] Very good.
